entry.title: Re: How to change the FYV in Make Company Code Seeting -...
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, only the configurable template fiscal year variant SZ is available for assignment. You cannot assign K4 directly to specific company codes. Instead, you should configure SZ to replicate the K4 settings (calendar year with 12 posting periods and 4 special periods but technically the variant is SZ.). This way, the two company codes will effectively follow K4 rules, while the system remains harmonized under SZ. Assigning different fiscal year variants to different company codes is not supported in Public Cloud.

entry.title: Re: Comments on BW/BPC live Connections in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Dieter,

So the first thing I need to know: have you given each MEMBER of the row and column structure a technical name? If so the remark in my blog above holds true:

  • If the restricted key figure has been given a technical name then we use the technical name as a key and do NOT resolve the selection. If you use a variable in the restriction then the variable name and the actual value of the variable are used in the key for the comment as well.

(the remark only talks about the restricted key figure but it is also true when you use a technical ID for a member of the second structure that does not involve the key figure.)

If this is the case you have to check get the technical name of the structure members from the context of the document and - if applicable - get the variable values that have been used when the comment was created. If you go back to the query you should be able to find the corresponding structure elements. If you now set the corresponding variable values you should find the comments. As the document service uses the ID of the structure element and NOT the underlying selection (this would be the case if you do NOT use an ID for the structure element), when building a query that uses the same underlying selection for a given cell but without the ID of the structure element then you would NOT see the comments. Is this maybe the problem you are facing?

Best regards

Gerd

entry.title: Re: Alternatif Payee For Customer
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the ‚Äúalternative payee‚Äù field is not available for customers in Accounts Receivable. Instead, the standard way to achieve this requirement is to assign the alternative customer (3000) as the Payer partner function in the BP master of customer 2000. When invoices are posted to 2000, the system will automatically set 3000 as the payer, so incoming payments (including partial payments) can be posted against 3000. This ensures that the invoice remains with customer 2000 for documentation, but settlement is handled by customer 3000.

entry.title: Re: Onboarding I-9 Form Verification Requiring Upload for...
entry.content:
Dear @JulieMcSwain 

Yes, it is required now.

USCIS Form I-9 - https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-onboarding/implementing-onboarding/uscis-form-i-9

  • The new hire must present one document from List A, or one document from both List B and List C. If the new hire presents a combination of List B and List C documents, then the List B document must contain a photograph.

Previously, the application permitted HR users to submit Form I-9 Section 2 without uploading at least one of the required documents (either a List A document or both List B and List C documents). No blocking or required enforcement was in place, leading to incomplete compliance records. 

This has been changed, making sure SAP is compliant with legal requirements.

US I-9 Central - https://www.uscis.gov/i-9-central/form-i-9-acceptable-documents

Best regards,
Jacson
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Price in Work Order
entry.content:
Why it happens only for stock components is because, stock components are materials that are managed in inventory (MM). Their valuation is maintained at plant level (valuation area). When you add a stock component to a work order, SAP pulls the valuation price (standard price or moving average) from the material master in that plant. That is why the price depends on the plant + material combination.

Non‚Äëstock components (e.g. direct procurement items, services, consumables) are not held in inventory. They don‚Äôt have plant‚Äëlevel valuation in the material master. Their cost is determined from purchase info records, planned price, or manually entered values in the order. Since there‚Äôs no plant valuation, you don‚Äôt see the same plant‚Äëdependent price behavior.

entry.title: Re: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recov...
entry.content: except if someone drops a table, then only a full database restore or Recyclebin option can be used to recover a dropped table. flashback table will fail if the DLL is changed. Flashback only works if data alone is changed, not the table structure itself.

entry.title: Re: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recov...
entry.content: Except that flashback table only works if the data alone was changed. If the table is altered or dropped, you cannot flashback the table, then you need Recyclebin or to do a database backup recovery to recover the table or restore it to another instance and copy the table. Both would take more time and effort than if we had Recyclebin enabled.

entry.title: New Course Extending SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 using SAP Build Code
entry.content:
Happy new year SAP CX Community! Fernando here, checking in and kicking off a new SAP CX Integration and Extensibility blog post.

From last year onwards, our learning production focus is on SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2 extensibility and integration topics. Today, I'm delighted to announce in this blog post the next major learning milestone for those looking to master the extensibility of SAP Sales and Service Cloud version 2 with SAP Build Code.

So, please, join me in welcoming our newest addition to the SAP's learning platform: 


New Course Extending SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 using SAP Build Code

If you're an extensibility developer looking to enhance SAP Sales and Service Cloud version 2 with mashups and microservices using your custom business logic, you've come to the right place. Here, you'll gain the practical knowledge needed to manage the entire end-to-end extensibility project.

We've structured our learning content to ensure that, after finishing this course developers and consultants will have the skills to code, deploy and configure mashups and microservices for SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2 using SAP Build Code.

Here's a glimpse of what it looks like:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Audience
The course is meant to be helpful for:

  • Developers
  • Technical Consultants
  • Architects

Learning Objectives
This course teaches how to build side by side extension apps with SAP Build Code to enhance SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2. You‚Äôll follow a practical development workflow covering app architecture, integration patterns, authentication, data mapping, testing, deployment, and maintenance.

Learning Content
The course consists of 3 units and provides more than 2 hours of content:

  • Exploring the Basics of Extending SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 with SAP Build Code
    Introduces side-by-side extensibility, the core extensibility features, SAP BTP account types, creating a BTP subaccount with a booster, configuring the Cloud Foundry environment, and setting up the SAP Build Code development environment. 
  • Creating a Mashup Webapp with SAP Build Code for SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2
    Guides through creating, deploying, configuring, and testing a mashup webapp from building a simple webapp and deploying it to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, developing the mashup webpage, configuring the mashup within Sales and Service Cloud, and validating the integration,
  • Creating a Microservice with SAP Build Code for SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2
    Teaches how to create and integrate microservices covering developing, configuring, and testing a custom logic microservice and a custom key-metric microservice.

After completing successfully this course you'll be granted with a digital badge like this one which could be shared and linked to your social networks:

Try it today!  we‚Äôre launching an exciting new series of extensibility learning content for SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version2, join us to boost your team‚Äôs skills and share feedback to help shape even better lessons.

Additional Resources
You can find a related live session on Extending SAP Sales Cloud version 2 with SAP Build. For additional free learning journeys and courses, visit the SAP Learning site for Integration and Extesibility to build in-demand SAP skills on a variety of topics, for the SAP CX Solutions portfolio. If you enjoy quick video learning, explore our Integration and Extensibility videos for SAP Customer Experience for the newest updates on integration and extensibility for SAP Customer Experience solutions.

entry.title: Re: Alternatif Payee For Customer
entry.content: Why you don‚Äôt see customer 3000 in FB70 / Post Incoming Payment is because, when you assign customer 3000 as the Payer in the BP master of customer 2000, the effect is at the SD billing level. That means, when you create a sales order ‚Üí billing document ‚Üí FI posting, the system automatically substitutes the payer (3000) in the accounting document. In other words, the invoice posted from SD will show 3000 as the account in FI, even though the sales order was created for 2000. If you post a purely FI invoice manually in FB70, the system does not look at SD partner functions. FB70 is a direct FI transaction, so it always posts to the customer you enter (2000). That‚Äôs why you don‚Äôt see 3000 there. To achieve the desired behavior, invoices should be created through SD billing so that the FI posting is automatically made to the payer (3000). Incoming payments, including partial payments, can then be posted against 3000.

entry.title: Re: How to group requirements across several WBS using va...
entry.content:
Why PMMO and GPD don‚Äôt fit is because, PMMO (Pegging, Distribution, and Summarization) is designed for non‚Äëvaluated project stock only. Great for logistics grouping, but not usable when you need valuated stock and FI postings.

GPD (Grouping, Pegging, Distribution) is technically supports both valuated and non‚Äëvaluated stock, but in S/4HANA 2021 it is deprecated. It only creates CO postings (in non‚Äëzero versions), not FI postings ‚Üí breaks your reporting and COGS alignment. So neither fits your requirement for valuated stock + FI postings.

Standard Options in S/4HANA 2021 are

1. Valuated Project Stock + Combined Orders without GPD
Keep each WBS element as the account assignment for its child orders. Use Combined Orders only for the common cutting/bending operations. After the header operation is confirmed, split into child orders pegged to the correct WBS. This way, costs flow to the WBS via the child orders, and FI postings are created because stock is valuated.

Downside: you lose the automatic ‚Äúrequirements grouping‚Äù across WBS, but you preserve FI integrity.

2. Network Activities with Valuated Stock
Instead of grouping via GPD, model the shared operations as network activities assigned to multiple WBS elements. You can issue materials to a network activity, capture costs, and then settle to the WBS. This gives you FI postings (because stock is valuated) and allows you to analyze costs per WBS. More flexible than combined orders, but requires careful design of networks.

3. Custom Extensibility for Grouping
Some customers build a custom grouping logic using extensibility (e.g. CDS views, allocation rules) to redistribute costs from a combined header order to multiple WBS elements. This way, you run one large production order, but at confirmation/settlement the system allocates costs to the relevant WBS. This preserves valuated stock and FI postings, but requires development effort.

4. Strategic Split of Projects
If grouping across WBS is essential, one option is to split the project definition so that the combined order can be tied to a single WBS/project, then allocate costs back to the ‚Äúreal‚Äù WBS hierarchy via settlement rules. Not elegant, but sometimes used when reporting requirements are strict.

entry.title: Re: How to group requirements across several WBS using valuated project stock?
entry.content:
A few clarifying points. PMMO is the latest improved version of GPD.  Both PMMO and GPD always required Non-Valuated Project Stock.  GPD does do FI postings, it is in the last Distribution step.  

Just Requirements Grouping can be used separate from GPD and can be used with Valuated Project Stock.  It also can be used in S/4HANA.

When you want to group requirements are you talking about grouping across projects or just within a project?  Either are possible.  This dictates how you do the grouping and subsequent Combined Order.

The Combined Orders use complicates the WBS account assignment.  I think all of the Production Orders in a Combined Order would need to have the same WBS account assignment.

entry.title: Display DRAFT Watermark on Adobe Form for Unapproved Purchase Orders
entry.content:
I have a requirement to display a DRAFT watermark on all pages of an Adobe form when a Purchase Order is not approved.

Below is the current setup:

  • We are using a custom Adobe form (copied from standard), with layout changes as per business requirements and custom fields added using Fiori applications.

  • The form uses the standard interface SOMU_DEFAULT_INTERFACE and OData service FDP_EF_PURCHASE_ORDER_SRV.

  • Standard output type: PURCHASE_ORDER.

  • We are using New Output Management (OPD, BRF+).

Form structure: Below forms are handled via the Fiori app Output Management Form Template.

  • Master Form: Used to display the logo dynamically based on configuration.

  • Content Form: Used to display transaction data.

What I have tried so far:

  • Placing a DRAFT image directly on the content form disrupts the existing layout (fields/subforms), so this approach did not work as expected.
  • Placing the DRAFT image/text on the master page of the content form shows correctly in design view but does not appear in the PO output.
  • Placing the DRAFT image on the main master form does display it in the PO output; however, I am unable to control its visibility (show/hide) based on the approval status, as the approval data is available only in the content form.

entry.title: Re: SAP CAP Lessons Learned: Hybrid Development with On-Premise SAP System
entry.content:
Hi @Ramjee_korada , 

Timeout errors usually means the connection is not setup correctly.

You'll have to use the command: 

cf ssh s4apitestproj-srv -L 2003:connectivityproxy.internal.cf.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com:20003

You correctly updated the onpremise_proxy_host value, but forgot to match the onpremise_proxy_port value.

The app by default will try to send the request to: connectivityproxy.internal.cf.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com:20003.

You'll first need to override the host to localhost. Then connect SSH to your remote app. Finally, tell your own computer that every time are request arrives at localhost:2003, it must forward - via ssh - to connectivityproxy.internal.cf.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com:20003.

entry.title: Why Vectorized Master Data is Critical for AI on SAP ECC and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Why Most AI Agents Fail with SAP Data

AI Agents are rapidly becoming part of enterprise landscapes, and SAP ECC and S/4HANA are obvious targets for automation. However, what we see in the market today is concerning.

Most agentic solutions attempt to consume SAP data through custom coding. This approach creates three major problems:

  1. High development and maintenance costs

  2. Multiple, inefficient calls to the SAP backend

  3. Mass data extraction, where AI Agents pull entire tables just to find a few relevant records

In many of the solutions we reviewed, including agentic SDKs integrations such as Joule, n8n, ChatGPT, and Claude, AI Agents frequently fail, time out, or request all records from SAP ERP systems with minimal filtering. This is inefficient, risky, and completely unnecessary.

At Skybuffer AI, we believe there is a better way.

The Foundation: Preparing SAP Data for AI Consumption

Data preparation is the key to successful AI-driven automation. While topics like data silos and data quality are well known, they cannot be fully solved overnight. Instead of fighting this reality, Skybuffer AI introduces a simple and reliable data layer that AI Agents can consume efficiently.

Skybuffer AI uses SAP master data vectorization to enable fast, accurate access to SAP ECC and S/4HANA data from agentic workflows. Any SAP master data table, including views and CDS views, can be vectorized and materialized using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).

Key capabilities include:

  • Support for full and delta loads

  • Near real-time synchronization with SAP

  • A scalable, AI-ready representation of SAP master data

 Pic. 1 Skybuffer AI ‚Äì SAP Data Vectorization Configuration

Performance at Enterprise Scale

A common concern is performance. Vectorizing SAP master data row by row would indeed be slow, if done sequentially.

Skybuffer AI solves this with parallel embedding execution, allowing vectorization at enterprise scale. On servers with 8 GPUs, Skybuffer AI can process up to 1 million records in 30 minutes. That is scalable in case even faster vectorization solution is needed.

More importantly, once initial vectorization is complete, a self-healing delta mechanism ensures that only new or changed records are processed. This keeps the data current without impacting performance.

Business Value: Why This Approach Matters

The benefits are immediate and measurable:

  • No coding for intelligent master data search

  • No multiple calls to SAP backend systems

  • No full-table reads triggered by AI Agents

  • Faster, more reliable AI-driven processes

Consider a real-world scenario:
A vendor invoice arrives by email.

Pic. 2 Real Consumption-Based Invoice Example

The AI Agent reads the email and attachment, extracts the vendor name exactly as written on the invoice, and needs the corresponding SAP vendor number. Instead of querying SAP repeatedly or scanning entire tables, the Agent performs one single RAG search against vectorized SAP master data.

Within milliseconds, the correct vendor record is returned. It is accurate, up to date, and ready for posting in SAP.

Pic. 3 Skybuffer AI ‚Äì Fast and Reliable SAP Data Search Using Data Vectorization

No coding. No overload. No hallucinations.

Applicable Across Many SAP Use Cases

The same approach works seamlessly across multiple scenarios, including:

  • Finding SAP users or business objects by name, email address, or other attributes

  • Creating Sales Orders in SAP from customer Purchase Orders

  • Resolving customer and material master data automatically

  • Creating Bills of Materials and routings from Excel files managed by R&D teams

  • Posting Service Entry Sheets

  • Rapidly enabling new use cases by simply nominating tables for vectorization

If the data exists in SAP, it can be prepared for AI consumption.

Built-In Authorization and Security

Security is not an afterthought.

Skybuffer AI applies the same concept used in AI assistants for Teams, Copilot, and Joule, so vectorized data accessed by users with an additional safeguard. Once the AI Agent selects relevant records via RAG, Skybuffer AI retrieves those records directly from SAP using SSO within the active conversation session, before providing data to the user.

This ensures:

  • Users only see data they are authorized to access in SAP

  • Vectorized data never bypasses SAP authorization rules

  • Enterprise-grade compliance and governance

Seamless Integration with Existing AI Agents

Already running AI Agents and just need access to SAP data?

Skybuffer AI provides an MCP Server, allowing your existing agentic solutions to consume vectorized SAP data without replacing your current platform. This makes Skybuffer AI an enabler, not a disruptor.

 Pic. 4 Skybuffer AI ‚Äì MCP Server for Integration with Agentic SDK

Flexible Deployment: Cloud or On-Premise

Skybuffer AI is built on SAP HANA and can be deployed:

  • On-premise within your own infrastructure

  • In your SAP BTP tenant

A modern SAP UI5 user interface ensures an intuitive and productive user experience for both IT and business users.

Conclusion

SAP ECC and S/4HANA master data vectorization is the missing link between SAP and AI Agents.

With Skybuffer AI, enterprises can:

  • Eliminate coding

  • Avoid hallucinations

  • Reduce SAP backend load

  • Enable fast, secure, and reliable AI-driven processes

This is how SAP data becomes truly AI-ready.

entry.title: Understanding SAP HANA Backup and Recovery - Technical Scope, Dependencies, and Design Boundaries
entry.content:
Introduction
SAP HANA provides a comprehensive and explicitly documented framework for backup and recovery. The core components of this framework are data backups, log backups, the backup catalog, and well-defined recovery procedures.

In many operational or architectural discussions, these components are treated as isolated features. From a technical perspective, however, recoverability is not a property of an individual backup. Recoverability emerges only from the complete and consistent backup chain over time, governed by strict dependencies that are explicitly documented by SAP.

This article consolidates SAP-documented SAP HANA backup and recovery mechanisms into a single coherent technical model.

Its objective is to make documented dependencies, scope, and design boundaries explicit, supporting sound architecture decisions, recovery validation planning, and technically correct discussions.

All statements in this article are derived from official SAP Help Portal and SAP HANA SQL Reference documentation.

1. Documented Core Components of SAP HANA Backup and Recovery
1.1 Data Backups
Data backups create a transaction-consistent image of the SAP HANA database at a defined point in time. SAP HANA supports different data backup types, such as full, differential, and incremental backups, each designed for specific operational and recovery scenarios.

A data backup establishes a single, consistent restore point.
However, a data backup does not define recoverability on its own.

From a technical perspective:

  • A data backup is a mandatory prerequisite for recovery.
  • Recoverability beyond the data backup timestamp depends on the availability of subsequent log backups and catalog metadata.

This distinction is explicitly reflected in SAP documentation.

SAP Help Portal reference
Backups (Overview)

Key technical boundary
A successful data backup defines a restore point, not continuous recoverability.

1.2 Log Backups
Log backups record all database changes that occur after a data backup. When log backup is enabled, SAP HANA generates log backups continuously.

From a recovery perspective, log backups are technically essential for:

  • recovery to the most recent state
  • point-in-time recovery

Log backups form a strictly sequential chain.
Recovery procedures that rely on log replay require this chain to be complete and uninterrupted.

If a required log backup segment is missing, corrupted, or no longer retained, recovery beyond that point is technically impossible, regardless of how many data backups exist.

SAP Help Portal reference
Log Backups

Key technical boundary
Log backups are not optional for recovery beyond a data backup timestamp.

1.3 Backup Catalog
The backup catalog stores metadata describing:

  • all data and log backups
  • their timestamps
  • their relationships and dependencies

SAP HANA uses the backup catalog to determine:

  • which backups exist
  • which backup chains are complete
  • which recovery targets are feasible

The backup catalog is therefore a technical dependency, not auxiliary metadata.

Even if backup files exist on disk or external storage, standard recovery procedures cannot be evaluated or executed without a consistent backup catalog.

SAP Help Portal reference
Backup Catalog

Additional technical detail:
What Information Is in the Backup Catalog?

Key technical boundary
Without a backup catalog, recoverability is limited and cannot be reliably determined.

2. Documented Recovery Capabilities and Scope
SAP HANA provides explicitly documented recovery procedures. The chosen recovery type determines which parts of the backup chain must be available.

2.1 Recovery to the Most Recent State
This recovery procedure restores the database to the latest possible point in time by:

  • restoring a suitable data backup
  • replaying all available log backups after that backup

Technical prerequisites:

  • a valid data backup
  • a complete and uninterrupted log backup chain
  • a consistent backup catalog

2.2 Point-in-Time Recovery
Point-in-time recovery restores the database to a specific timestamp.

From a technical standpoint:

  • all log backups covering the requested time range must be available
  • the backup catalog must describe the full chain

If required log backups for the selected interval are missing, recovery to that timestamp is not possible, even if older data backups exist.

SAP Help Portal reference
Point-In-Time Recovery of a Primary System

3. Recoverability as a Chain Property (Technical Dependency Model)
Recoverability is not a property of an individual backup artifact.

From a technical perspective, recovery depends on the combined availability of:

  • a suitable data backup
  • all required log backups following that backup
  • the corresponding backup catalog entries

SAP HANA tooling evaluates these dependencies using catalog-driven logic when determining feasible recovery options.

This behavior is explicitly reflected in the SAP HANA SQL Reference.

SAP HANA SQL Reference
BACKUP LIST DATA Statement

Documented boundary
Without a backup catalog, recovery capabilities are restricted

4. Retention and Recovery Window
Retention settings define how long data and log backups are kept.
From a technical standpoint, retention directly defines the recovery window.

If required log backups are no longer available:

  • recovery beyond that point is technically impossible
  • older data backups do not extend recoverability

This follows directly from SAP HANA‚Äôs log replay mechanics.

SAP Help Portal reference
Planning Your Backup and Recovery Strategy

5. Backup Operation Success vs. Recoverability
SAP HANA reports the success or failure of individual backup operations.

From a technical perspective:

  • backup success confirms that a single operation completed
  • recoverability is evaluated only at restore time

Recovery feasibility depends on:

  • chain completeness
  • catalog availability
  • chosen recovery target

Backup operations are events.
Recovery is a reconstruction procedure.
These are technically distinct concepts.

6. Separation from Availability Mechanisms
SAP HANA provides availability mechanisms such as system replication to reduce downtime. Backup and recovery address restoration to a previous state.

These mechanisms serve different documented objectives and must be designed and validated independently.

(Availability mechanisms are intentionally not covered in this article.)

Summary
SAP HANA provides all documented technical mechanisms required for reliable backup and recovery.

Recoverability is defined by the availability and consistency of the complete backup chain over time:

  • data backups
  • log backups
  • backup catalog

Understanding these documented dependencies and boundaries is essential for technically sound architecture design, realistic recovery expectations, and precise operational discussions.

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite: Q4/2025 Feature Highlights
entry.content:
The fresh batch of features delivered in Q4 2025 brings powerful new tools designed to make your integrations smarter, faster, and more resilient. From AI-powered recommendations that simplify troubleshooting, to streamlined connectivity with top platforms like Amazon Kinesis and Box, these updates are crafted to boost your operational efficiency and keep you ahead of the curve. Read on to explore how these innovations can transform your integration experience.

Artificial Intelligence

AI-based intelligent recommendations for detected API anomalies

This AI enhancement builds on anomaly detection to explain what changed, why it likely happened, and what to do next, cutting triage and speeding recovery. Embedded in API Management, it surfaces guidance alongside alerts with one-click actions and optional ‚Äúintelligent healing.‚Äù

The included capabilities - Insights, Causes, and Recommendations - enable faster response to error spikes, latency surges, and abnormal traffic patterns, improving reliability and operational efficiency for API owners and teams. See how to get started in this blog post and review the Documentation.

 Connectivity and Adapters

  • Amazon Kinesis receiver adapter: facilitates and accelerates connectivity to Amazon Kinesis Data Streams, streamlining data communication and enhancing real-time data processing.
  • Box receiver adapter: connects SAP Integration Suite to Box and enables you to access components on Box.
  • Microsoft OneNote receiver adapter: automates common business operations by integrating MS OneNote with other business applications. It connects an SAP Integration Suite tenant to a remote system using HTTP protocol.
  • Azure Service Bus adapter: connects SAP Integration Suite to Azure Service Bus.
  • MongoDB receiver adapter: connects SAP Integration Suite to MongoDB.
  • Poll Enrich Step in FTP sender adapter: reads (poll) messages from FTP server and adds the content to the original message in the middle of the message processing sequence.

New data space integration package

The data space integration package helps supply chain partners exchange data securely and self-sovereignly within data spaces. It includes two components: a data space connector for secure, sovereign data exchange, and a decentralized identity wallet for sharing trustworthy, verifiable data. Read all details in the blog post.

Data Center Availability üá©üá™ üáÆüáπ üá¶üá™

Customers can now run SAP Integration Suite in four new data centers: on SAP infrastructure in Frankfurt, Sankt Leon-Rot (both in Germany) and in the United Arab Emirates; and additionally, one in Italy on Amazon Web Services.

Event-driven Integration 

Micro-Integrations

Micro-Integrations are small, event-driven connectors that link applications to an Advanced Event Mesh as on-ramps (event sources) or off-ramps (event targets), avoiding brittle point-to-point ties so changes stay localized and low-risk. By focusing on narrowly defined tasks, they are easier to design, adapt, and scale, delivering high-throughput, real-time streams via pub/sub and letting you add more Micro-Integrations per task as demand grows. Available in the Cloud Console, they provide management and observability for integrations between external systems and event brokers or meshes, resulting in greater agility, faster data distribution, and flexibility to use the best-fit technologies at the source and target. Find more details and the currently available micro-integrations in the blog post.

Event Mesh integration with SAP Cloud ALM for health monitoring

SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs Event Mesh now integrates with SAP Cloud ALM Health Monitoring to regularly collect and display broker vitals, such as active connections, message consumers, message queues, spool usage, and broker state, on the CALM dashboard. Customers can customize thresholds for each metric (except broker state), view 14 days of history, and receive warning notifications when values reach 80% (orange) and 90% (red) of the defined thresholds, enabling proactive monitoring and alerts for Event Mesh health. Set up and further details can be found here.

Migration support from Event Mesh capability to SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh

Great news to facilitate your system modernization: SAP provides technical- and process-oriented migration support to help customers move from the Event Mesh capability in SAP Integration Suite to SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh, scaling smoothly from basic scenarios to a richer, more powerful event-driven foundation. This includes support for migrating events so applications can communicate asynchronously in real time across distributed landscapes with support for various protocols, enabling teams to start simple, grow confidently, and modernize without disruption.

B2B Integration

Support for the SFTP adapter and Alerting of failed B2B interchanges in Trading Partner Management

SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs Trading Partner Management now supports SFTP (Secure File Transfer Protocol), available in both standard and premium editions and via the SAP BTP Enterprise Agreement. Users can read and write files to their own or trading partners‚Äô SFTP servers and, when defining systems, can choose SFTP sender and receiver adapters.

Additionally, SAP Integration Suite extends Trading Partner Management by publishing B2B interchange data to SAP Cloud ALM for centralized monitoring and rapid detection of failed transactions. Using SAP Cloud ALM, you can configure granular scenario specific alerts that filter by details such as trading partners or message types to receive targeted notifications and act quickly on issues.

Process Integration

Basic authentication on Edge Integration Cell

SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs Edge Integration Cell now supports basic HTTP authentication using a client ID and client secret during temporary connectivity loss to SAP BTP. This enables simple sender authentication for testing with minimal configuration and allows integration flow processing and API artifact invocations using clientId and clientsecret while SAP BTP is unreachable.

Advanced checks in Groovy scripts

SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs Cloud Integration designer now offers advanced checks for Groovy scripts, helping developers analyze and prepare custom integration flows for future runtime version upgrades. A new ‚Äúensure upgrade readiness‚Äù guideline recommends supported libraries and classes and can automatically update scripts to align with upgrade requirements. See all information in the respective documentation.

Service interface artifact creation In Cloud Integration

SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration now supports creating and editing service interface artifacts directly in the workspace, aligning with an API first outside in development approach and supporting existing Enterprise Services Repository use cases. These artifacts enable proxy generation in ABAP backends for smooth integration into ABAP based systems. The capability is available in the multi cloud environment and allows native creation of service interface artifacts in your Cloud Integration tenant.

----

  • For a sneak peek into what‚Äôs in store for 2026, check out the road map explorer and the SAP TechEd 2025 News Guide
  • Join the integration community and connect with other integration developers!

entry.title: SAP Group Reporting Implementation: Architecture and Methodology for Success
entry.content:
Hello dear colleagues and readers, I`d like to appreciate you for your 
attention to this material, what, I`m sure, will assist you during your SAP Group Reporting solution implementation.

Let`s get started

Agenda:
1) SAP Group Reporting. Why business needs this solution,
2) SAP Activate methodology, in a nutshell,
3) High lvl overview SAP Group Reporting implementation steps,
4) Successful Go - Live timeline, linkage SAP Activate Methodology and SAP Group Reporting,
5) DEV - TEST - PROD consistency must be aligned between these instances,
6) Unit test, SIT, UAT. Main idea.


GROUP REPORTING: Why Business Needs This Solution
SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud for Group Reporting is an integrated consolidation solution that
helps organizations efficiently collect, aggregate, validate, and prepare
financial data for consolidated financial statement reporting.

1. DATA MONITOR - Responsible for:
- Collecting financial data from consolidation units (local companies),
- Validating data quality at the source level,
- Preparing and transforming data before consolidation,
- Performing local reporting tasks per consolidation unit.

2. CONSOLIDATION MONITOR - Responsible for:
- Consolidating data across all consolidation units at group level,
- Executing consolidation procedures (intercompany eliminations, currency translations, investment consolidation),
- Performing group - level validations and adjustments,
- Generating consolidated financial statements.

DELIVERABLES - Consolidated Financial Statements:
The solution produces comprehensive consolidated financial statements including:
* Consolidated Balance Sheet (Statement of Financial Position),
* Consolidated Profit & Loss Statement (Income Statement),
* Statement of Changes in Equity,
* Consolidated Cash Flow Statement,
* Segment Reporting (if required by business),
* Additional reports based on business requirements.

KEY DIFFERENTIATORS:
Universal Journal Integration:
Unlike legacy consolidation tools (like BPC), SAP Group Reporting is fully embedded in
SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and directly accesses the Universal Journal (ACDOCA/ACDOCU).
This creates a "single version of truth" - meaning local operational data
and group - level consolidation data come from the same source, eliminating
data replication and reconciliation challenges.

Real-Time Consolidation:
SAP Group Reporting enables continuous consolidation rather than batch - based
processing, allowing consolidation to be performed before and after the monthly close.

Comprehensive Consolidation Capabilities:
1) Full consolidation of subsidiaries,
2) Equity method consolidation for joint ventures and associates,
3) Automatic intercompany transaction elimination,
4) Currency translation per regulatory requirements (IFRS,US - GAAP),
5) Investment consolidation (goodwill, NCI),
6) Data validation at multiple levels (reported, standardized, consolidated),
7) Multi - dimensional reporting (by Legal entity, Profit Center, Cost Center and another).

Why it`s important for business:
1) Faster consolidation cycles,
2) Improved data quality,
3) Better visibility and transparency,
4) Compliance from regulatory point of view,
5) Reduced manual effort,
6) Flexibility for complex organizations.


SAP Activate Methodology, in a nutshell
It`s a standard Best Practice implementation road map of SAP S/4HANA (Public/Privat cloud) solutions, and sure it`s absolutely
relevant for SAP Group Reporting.
Please take a look at these 6 main steps, it's critical for timeline perspective alignment:





Successful Go - Live timeline, linkage SAP Activate Methodology and SAP Group Reporting

I would like to emphasize a critical point regarding alignment with the roadmap and implementation approach
aligned with Road Map and implementation.
It is essential to strictly adhere to the proposed SAP Activate methodology all standard steps - both in terms of gathering business information and implementing the corresponding system configuration.
Any delays or deviations from the planned timeline will inevitably impact the Go - Live schedule and all associated consequences.
If any deliverable is at risk of missing its deadline, it is crucial to immediately notify the Project Management persons so they can respond promptly and implement corrective measures to get the project back on track.

DEV - TEST - PROD consistency must aligned between these instances

When you configure SAP Group Reporting in DEV system, that configuration must be exactly replicated in TEST and PROD systems.
If they're different = disaster.
SAP provides Transport Management System (TMS) to move configuration between environments.




Unit test, SIT, UAT. Main idea.

Unit Testing can be performed based on abstract data during initial configuration activities, primarily to ensure that individual system components work as expected in isolation. Unit tests validate single configuration elements without considering how they interact with other parts of the system.

System Integration Testing (SIT) activities must be performed based on REAL BUSINESS DATA with EXPECTED RESULTS provided by the Finance team. For example, when testing P&L Functional Area with Reporting Rules, the Finance team must provide the consolidated P&L that should be produced as output. SIT validates that all configuration components work together end-to-end and produce the correct consolidated financial statements.

User Acceptance Testing (UAT) is performed by the Finance/IT business department using actual business data and real consolidation scenarios. During UAT, business users validate that the system meets their requirements and they can perform their daily work. UAT concludes with explicit sign - off from Finance confirming the system is ready for Go - Live.

The critical difference:
1) Unit tests validate components individually,
2) SIT validates the entire system with real data against expected results,
3) UAT validates that business users accept the solution before Go - Live.


I hope my experience will assists you in the next implementation projects.
Many thanks for your attention, all the best.

Let`s keep in touch.
https://www.linkedin.com/in/eugene-kavaleu/

entry.title: SAP Service and Asset Manager 2511 Now Available ‚Äì What‚Äôs New?
entry.content:
SAP Service and Asset Manager continues to expand mobile execution across service, maintenance, and logistics processes. The 2511 release introduces new confirmation scenarios, more flexible synchronization options, workflow and usability enhancements, expanded logistics and warehouse capabilities, and broader forms support‚Äîhelping field teams collaborate more effectively, reduce manual effort, and execute work with greater accuracy and control.

Key features delivered in the SAP Service and Asset Manager 2511 release

Confirmation scenarios

Confirmation scenarios enable technicians to apply confirmations using secure, QR code‚Äìbased authentication, improving collaboration, accountability, and quality assurance.

When working with an operation or suboperation, two technicians use their devices to complete a confirmation. An authorized or supporting technician generates a QR code, which is scanned to automatically populate confirmation details and reduce manual entry.

Cooperation

The primary technician records work performed by a supporting technician by scanning a QR code generated on the supporting technician‚Äôs device, creating a clear and auditable record of collaborative work.

Verification

Verification supports a four-eyes principle by requiring an authorized technician to review and confirm completed work. Verification can be configured as mandatory, preventing confirmation until the review is completed.

Upload-only syncing

Upload-only syncing allows users to upload recorded transactions without triggering an immediate delta download. This decouples upload and download activities, improving sync efficiency in offline or low-connectivity environments.

Technicians can upload transactions after completing a job, finishing a shift, or completing a work cycle, while still initiating a full delta sync whenever updated data is required.

Maintenance workflow enhancements

Workflow and usability enhancements help technicians collaborate more effectively and complete work faster.

Improvements to split capacity assignment

Split capacity assignment now better supports multi-technician execution. Technicians can view all assigned splits, track split-specific dates, include split numbers in confirmations, and record confirmations on behalf of other users‚Äîimproving flexibility while maintaining accurate effort tracking.

Tabbed layout for the home page

A new tabbed home page layout organizes content into clearly defined sections, enabling faster navigation and easier access to relevant information.

Enhanced navigation for related orders and notifications

Navigation to related orders and notifications has been streamlined. If the related object is available on the device, users are taken directly to it. If not, an online search can be initiated from the related items list to retrieve the required details.

Advanced map features

Mapping enhancements include support for vector tile basemaps and improved offline map handling with support now for .tpk and .geodatabase files as well as side-loading of map cache. Technicians can use vector and raster maps offline, view GIS feature layer attributes, and trigger actions such as completing forms or measurement readings directly from the map, improving performance and productivity for location-based work.

Field Service Technician updates

New capabilities support external technicians and improve schedule visibility for field service teams.

External Field Service Technician persona

A new persona supports integration with FSM Crowd Service, enabling third-party technicians to view and execute service orders directly in the mobile app. External technicians can record time, materials, and expenses without requiring individual SAP user IDs, increasing flexibility and field productivity.

Enhanced calendar with event and task indicators

A new calendar control on the home page provides visual indicators for open and overdue tasks, helping technicians quickly prioritize work. Daily, weekly, and monthly views improve schedule awareness and task management.

Expanded logistics and warehouse support

Logistics teams gain expanded mobile access to core SAP processes, enabling faster and more accurate execution in warehouse and field logistics scenarios.

Inbound delivery support for Extended Warehouse Management

The Extended Warehouse Clerk persona now supports inbound delivery processing on mobile. Users can search for inbound deliveries, update documents, create warehouse tasks, perform packing, and post goods receipt for single or multiple items.

Return and packing features

Field logistics operators can initiate returns by product or by order and perform packing activities directly on mobile, including packing containers, assigning them to voyages, sealing, and dispatching‚Äîstreamlining logistics execution and improving visibility.

Expanded forms support

Forms capabilities have been extended to reduce manual entry and support safety-related workflows.

Dynamic predefined text in smartform fields

Smartform fields can now display dynamic predefined text, such as service order numbers, directly in input controls, improving consistency and reducing manual data entry on Customer Service and S/4HANA systems.

Safety Technician persona support for SAP Dynamic Forms

The Safety Technician persona now supports SAP Dynamic Forms, allowing creation, editing, and submission of forms attached to work permits, isolation certificates, and other safety-related certificates. Forms attached to other object types remain read-only.

Configuration details

Features described above may be optional and not be default-enabled, and integrations with other SAP products may require additional licensing.

Please refer to Configuring Features and Personas in SAP Service and Asset Manager to learn about assigning personas and visit the Features and Personas Configuration Matrix to see which features are in-scope for each persona .

Release available now

The application is publicly available and includes an offline demo mode for viewing and testing the extensive functionality with maintenance technician, field service technician, safety technician, and inventory clerk personas included.

The application metadata is now available for licensed customers and partners on the SAP Support Portal Software Center and the mobile client may be downloaded from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store.

Share your ideas

We encourage you to learn more about submitting improvement requests to influence future releases of SAP Service and Asset Manager.

entry.title: Beyond Data Mesh: Entering the Data Product Economy with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
The challenge of the modern enterprise is not a lack of data, but a lack of business context and accessibility. The traditional approach of monolithic centralized approaches struggled to scale, leading to the adoption of Data Mesh principles.

For those unacquainted with the term, Data Mesh is an organizational and architectural shift that rejects the idea of a single, central platform owning all data. Instead, it federates ownership to the respective business domains, ensuring that data is managed by those with the semantic understanding of its content. This eliminates the "bottleneck" of central IT and fosters agility.

To understand how SAP Business Data Cloud enables Data Mesh approaches read my previous blog: From Vision to Reality: Enabling Data Mesh with SAP Business Data Cloud

However, decentralization carries its own risk: without a mechanism for exchange, it can simply create fragmented islands of information. To prevent this, we must layer an economic model on top of the architectural mesh.

A Data Mesh is just the factory. A factory is useless without a Market. 

We are moving beyond the broad "Data Economy," where data is often hoarded like a raw commodity, towards a "Data Product Economy." In this model, data is cultivated, packaged with business context, and consumed like a finished product enabling a seamless flow of value across the organization.

Here is how this Data Product Economy functions in practice.In a traditional setup, IoT data sits in a data lake while ERP data sits in SAP, leading to reactive "fire-fighting" when assets fail. In the Data Product Economy, we treat these inputs as valuable raw materials to manufacture a premium internal product.

The Producers: The Engineering domain provides real-time IoT condition data (vibration, temperature) without moving it, thanks to Zero Copy. Simultaneously, the Supply Chain domain provides Spare Parts Classification and Lead Times as governed data products.

The Product: These inputs are combined to create a consumer-oriented "Predictive Failure Risk" product. This is further refined into a "Preventive Service Plan"‚Äîa high-level data product containing specific service actions and scheduling windows.

The Value: The Service Department "buys" this product to generate a preventive maintenance schedule, resulting in higher asset availability and reduced SLA penalties.Reporting CO2 footprint and costs at a product level is often impossible due to data silos. In the Data Product Economy, sustainability becomes a transparent supply chain of information.

The Producers: The Manufacturing domain offers Energy Metering and Machine Run-time as products. The S/4HANA Finance domain contributes Product Costing Structures and Supplier data.

The Product: These are orchestrated‚Äînot replicated‚Äîto build a "CO2 & Cost Allocation Model per Product". This feeds into the ultimate 2nd-level product: a "Customer-Ready ESG Report".

The Value: The C-Suite uses this product for steering investment decisions, while Sales uses it to provide auditable reporting to customers and regulators, turning compliance into a competitive advantage.Previously, finance data lived in the ERP and clickstream data lived in marketing, leaving the organization exposed to revenue leakage and financial risk. The Data Product Economy breaks this silo by treating risk scoring as a shared enterprise asset.

The Producers: The Digital team provides Clickstream and Session Pattern Analytics. The Finance team provides Journal Entries and Payment history.

The Product: By linking these via shared semantic keys, the organization creates a "Risk Behaviour Score per Customer". This powers a "Fraud Intervention Feed" specifically designed for Finance Operations.

The Value: Instead of random sampling, the Finance team consumes this feed to prioritize investigations, enabling near real-time detection of suspicious activity and significantly faster intervention.

Conclusion: The Currency of the Future Building a Data Mesh gives you the infrastructure‚Äîthe roads and highways. But a road system is worthless without commerce. By transitioning to the Data Product Economy, you stop treating data as a static asset to be stored and start treating it as a dynamic currency to be invested.

Whether it is trading "Data for Uptime" in the Service Economy , "Data for Compliance" in the Green Ledger Economy , or "Data for Trust" in the Trust Economy, the principle remains the same: Value is only created when data moves, connects, and transacts.

In the era of Agentic AI, your Data Products become the essential fuel for autonomous agents. SAP Business AI relies on this semantic layer to understand the context of your business, ensuring that algorithms do not merely generate content, but execute valid business actions. Without the governance and context of a Data Product, AI is a risk; with it, it becomes a trusted partner for automation.

To accelerate this transition, you do not need to build every data product from scratch. SAP Managed Data Products represent the fastest and most efficient route to market maturity. This efficiency is backed by rigorous analysis: a joint study by SAP and PwC found that utilizing SAP Managed Data Products can realize a savings potential of 69% compared to custom development approaches (read the full study here: Unlocking Business Value with SAP Business Data Cloud).

The Data Product Economy enables you to turn the Data Office from a cost center of "storage managers" into a profit center of "product managers". The technology is ready with SAP Business Data Cloud. The question is: Is your mindset?

Don't just build a Data Mesh. Build a Data Product Economy.


.

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Connector Subaccount Certificate Automated Renewal has arrived!!
entry.content:
Cloud Connector 2.18.1 and 2.18.1.2 is the same patch level. Currently supported are 2.18.2, 2.18.1 (including 2.18.1.2), and 2.17.2 (latest patch level of previous feature release). See also https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/cloud-connector-faq#administration :

Does SAP provide support for older Cloud Connector versions?
SAP supports the latest 2 feature releases in parallel. For the latest feature release, the last 2 patch levels are supported. For the previous feature release, only its latest patch level is supported.
For more information on the Cloud Connector support strategy, see SAP Note 3302250.

entry.title: Re: SAP Companion Setup in S4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

 

There are three content scenarios for SAP Enable Now:

Standard Content Scenario - Provides SAP standard content for your apps.

Extended Content Scenario - Provides SAP standard content for your apps. Allows you to customize the standard content and to add user-defined content.

Custom Content Scenario - Allows you to add user-defined content for your apps.

For the custom content scenario, an SAP Enable Now instance is required to edit and store the content on the SAP Enable Now Manager. Check Integrating SAP Enable Now and Custom Content Scenario for more details.

 

To use the extended or custom content scenario of SAP Companion, you can add an SAP Enable Now Manager to your configuration. 

Check Setup Checklist and Setup of SAP Companion for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Similar Systems for more details.

 

Kind regards,

SAP Support.

entry.title: PyRFC is unmaintained ‚Äî calling SAP RFC directly from Python using nwrfcsdk
entry.content:
Since PyRFC is no longer actively maintained and there‚Äôs no official replacement,
one practical alternative is using the SAP NetWeaver RFC SDK (nwrfcsdk) directly
from Python via ctypes. This avoids PyRFC entirely while still allowing RFC/BAPI
calls and table extraction (including nested structures).

I‚Äôve shared some working examples of this approach here:
https://github.com/jdsricardo/SAP-RFC-Python-without-PyRFC

This might help anyone looking for a PyRFC-free path forward.
